awd_titl_txt: Drone Research and Opportunities for Native Elementary Students (DRONES)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing and testing a career exploration experience for upper elementary students. The project will engage students and their teachers within three rural school districts of Alaska: a rural coastal hub having a diverse population, a rural fringe community with an even mix of Native and non-Native residents, and a remote rural district primarily accessible by air or boat having a predominately Alaska Native population. The project encourages students and their communities to envision how unmanned aerial systems (UAS) can be used to address local priorities, such as wildlife management, search and rescue operations, and monitoring of hazards. In this context, the project will develop, implement, and test a place-based education strategy that includes a teacher professional development course, three culturally inclusive curriculum units focusing on STEM fields, and UAS-focused career exploration experiences. The project aims to increase Alaska Native students' enthusiasm, engagement, and success in STEM education. 

This mixed-methods comparative case study responds to three identified problems within the schools and communities participating in the project.  These include: 1) a lack of culturally relevant curriculum and educational resources, 2)inexperienced educators who are unprepared for rural Alaska settings; and 3)limited opportunities for local STEM mentorship and STEM workforce learning opportunities. In this context, the overarching goal of the project is to increase Alaska Native students' enthusiasm, engagement, and success in STEM learning. The associated research goal is to identify key factors and strategies that engender this success in STEM subjects. To achieve these goals, the project aims to: 1) engage students and communities in identifying locally relevant UAS applications; 2) develop science and technology curricula related to place-based UAS applications; 3) develop a distance-delivered continuing education course for upper-elementary teachers; 4)train up to 23 elementary school teachers to instruct science and technology using place-based pedagogies; and 5)deliver the DRONES curricula and an associated year-end career exploration experience to three school districts serving a total of 450 4th through 6th grade students in 14 rural Alaska communities. A backwards design process will be used for curriculum development to ensure that project deliverables address targeted Alaska cultural standards, Next Generation Science Standards, Alaska science standards, and 21st Century Competencies. Alaska Native cultural values will be identified, and key terminology will be translated into relevant Athabascan dialects to encourage community support.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drone Research and Opportunities for Native Elementary Students (DRONES) encouraged rural students and communities to envision local uses for unmanned aerial systems (i.e. wildlife management, search and rescue). The project was designed for Alaska, where about half its residents live in geographically isolated territory. Alaska Natives are the majority in many of these communities.

Alaska has the highest percentage of Indigenous students in the Nation. Compared to other states, Alaska ranks near the bottom academically, illustrating the need for studies focused on effectiveness of educational strategies and approaches for Native learners. DRONES focused on developing locally relevant curricula as a tool to increase student engagement. Student engagement, enthusiasm and success in STEM is a critical educational need to prepare students for the globally competitive workforce.

Intellectual merits focused on advancing new knowledge around engaging community members--especially Alaska Native leaders from rural communities--in codesigning curriculum. At project end, research yielded three empirical studies, which are undergoing peer review:

1. An autoethnography exploring the roles of interdisciplinary teams in doing community-based projects with Indigenous partners was developed in response to a growing literature concerning community-engaged and participatory research, but a noted gap around implementation projects. Findings argue that time devoted to understanding the professional and personal expectations, experiences, and motivations team members bring to interdisciplinary work is a requisite for grant success and merits attention in project management.

2) A phenomenology of the growing connections experienced by teachers while implementing a locally developed curriculum noted that much of the literature on place-based education is focused on student outcomes; less attention is given to the outcomes and experiences of teachers who must design and customize these units. In response to this gap in the literature, this study found locally developed units can scaffold teachers to better connections with students, community, and land.

3. A case study of Indigenous community members' priorities for local use of new technologies in science education addressed a gap in literature around community priorities for school-based science curricula. Interview data with community participants noted that when considering the introduction of new technologies into the curriculum, community members prioritize authentic local applications, centering local culture/knowledge, and attention to community priorities and values (with mindfulness that, without community inclusion, technology has as much power to be destructive as to serve).

Broader impacts stem from the engagement of rural communities in development of five videos, four place-based curricular units, three teacher training videos and a handful of other resources. The UAF Cultural Connections Process Model was used as a tool guiding participant roles and interactions. Products feature rural Alaskans and UAF researchers sharing knowledge. Four Native organizations and over a dozen industry, government and academic partners collaborated in development.

Rural residents selected STEM themes and related concepts and translated vocabulary into three Indigenous languages.

Curricula and kits containing teaching supplies were distributed to rural partners: Nenana City Schools, Valdez City Schools and Yukon Koyukuk School District. Copper River School District, which neighbors Valdez City Schools and the Fairbanks North Star Borough School District's Alaska Native Education Program also received kits, although not as project partners.

Our final visits to Nenana, Nulato and Valdez allowed us to meet with Tribal leaders, teachers and school administrators. Teachers who piloted the kits and then gave feedback, were eager to see the final products.

"This is truly cutting edge" said Nenana School District Superintendent Patrick Manning regarding the full-color, graphically driven, place-based student guides. He said the school district will use the kits and would be happy to collaborate on new projects. Nenana Native Association First Chief Caroline Ketzler agreed, as she reviewed the printed materials. She commented on their professional appearance, and asked how to support our future efforts.

Nulato's elementary teacher, who field-tested two units with his students spanning second-sixth grade, asked for new curricula. He explained he could not re-teach what they had piloted, since too many students who worked with those resources were again in his classroom. He was happy to see two other units--developed with Nenana and Valdez--with drone-related content. The cultural educator in the same school said he would be using some DRONES activities in his class, and would use/teach the translated words so student learning from the science classroom could be reinforced.

A DRONES teaching kit was provided to the University of Alaska Museum of the North for its kit lending and training program, which serves educators statewide. Fairbanks area teachers can borrow the kits at no cost. The curricula can be downloaded from the project website, which also hosts project media and its online language tool.

At least 30 elementary teachers and over 1000 students (grades 4-6) have been directly served. Broader, more diverse audiences have been reached through at least nine conference presentations and dissemination as an exhibitor at the 2024 National Science Teaching Association meeting.
